thread.title: How Steve Spurrier left a permanent stamp on college football
thread.title_full: How Steve Spurrier left a permanent stamp on college football

title: How Steve Spurrier left a permanent stamp on college football
text:
South Carolina Gamecocks head coach Steve Spurrier reacts during the second half at Williams-Brice Stadium. (Photo: Jim Dedmon, USA TODAY Sports)
180 CONNECT 115 TWEET 1 LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE He was always good with a Quote: .
Peyton Manning returned for his senior season at Tennessee because "he wanted to be a three-time star" of the defunct Citrus Bowl; after all, you couldn't spell Citrus "without U-T," Steve Spurrier remarked.
He liked coaching against Georgia early, in the first month of the season, "because you could always count on them having two or three key players suspended."
MORE COVERAGE: Spanning the SEC
FSU stood not for Florida State but "Free Shoes University," after the rival Seminoles were caught in a footwear-related booster scandal in 1994. A year later, Florida threw a touchdown pass against Georgia with just over a minute left to stretch its lead over the Bulldogs to 52-17. Why?
"We wanted to score 50 because it had never been done," Spurrier said afterward. "Isn't that what you're supposed to do?"
USA TODAY
South Carolina coach Steve Spurrier to retire
Anyone who thinks defense wins championships, well, "hasn't watched us a lot." Asked how his South Carolina team beat Tennessee in 2006, he replied, "The same way Vanderbilt did."
In a world of cookie-cutter, cliché-spouting peers and colleagues, Spurrier — who will retire from coaching — always had time for a jab. Tennessee was always on Spurrier's radar. So was Georgia. Florida State. Clemson. Rivals circled around Spurrier like planets, but make no mistake: Spurrier was always the center of the universe.
He won at Duke, a feat that remains noteworthy — Duke , italicized — even as David Cutcliffe nears Spurrier's success decades later. He returned to his alma mater, Florida, in 1990, 24 years after winning the Heisman Trophy, viewed as the program's savior.
Former Florida coach Steve Spurrier is carried off the field in 2000. (Photo: Associated Press)
He changed the landscape of the Southeastern Conference. Bear Bryant still loomed over the conference in the decade following his death; Spurrier was the coach of a new generation, one more willing to rewrite plays, invent schemes, toss out musty philosophies and — in his most stunning quirk — pass the football.
The Gators went 122-27-1 from 1990-2001, winning one national title, in 1996, and six conference championships. Florida never finished below No. 14 in the Amway Coaches Poll, and six times inside the top six. After finishing No. 3 in 2001, Spurrier left for the Washington Redskins. His replacement, Ron Zook, told Spurrier he was a tough act to follow; "I told him that's why he got hired," he answered.
The current SEC — more open, often pass-based, on the cutting edge offensively — was born from Spurrier, who took decades of unoriginality and went vertical. He led the only team in the modern era to score at least 500 points in six seasons in a row, from 1993-98. That 1996 team scored at least 28 points in every game but one, a 24-21 regular-season loss to Florida State; the Gators' revenge came in a 52-20 victory in the Sugar Bowl, claiming the national championship.
Follow the road to the 2015 College Football Playoff at The Football Four , our home to rate and debate the nation's best. Returning to the SEC at South Carolina in 2005, Spurrier learned new tricks: The Gamecocks were built more on the ground, with defense, pulling his offense back from the edge of innovation — and still he found success, setting a school record for wins, 86, and from 2011-13 notching the greatest three-year run in program history.
He beat Clemson, again and again, and had the upper hand on his in-state counterpart, Dabo Swinney. When Swinney suggested that he was from Pluto and Spurrier from Mars, Spurrier replied, "Dabo still thinks there are 9 planets out there."
He was always quotable, never boring. Always a winner, until this fall, when the Gamecocks — clearly lacking the talent needed to compete in the SEC — lost four of their first six, the latest a 45-20 defeat to LSU.
USA TODAY
Fournette, No. 5 LSU too much for displaced South Carolina
Spurrier once said he didn't want to coach too far into his 60s; by that point, he'd be playing golf "four of five times a week." That he lasted until 70 is a testament to his success at South Carolina. That Spurrier retired at the midway point of his 26th season as a college coach means he realized: It had grown stale — and it was time.
He leaves behind 228 wins, the second-most in SEC history, and that national title, and remade two programs — leading the first to historic heights. Yet the legacy is broader.
USA TODAY HIGH SCHOOL SPORTS
Recruits react to Steve Spurrier's retirement, including one de-commitment
He liked being called an "offensive mastermind," and earned the title: Spurrier led the embrace of the passing game across college football, now the in-vogue style in every conference in the country. He liked being the smartest guy in the room, and in the world of football coaches, he was.
He rewrote record books. Had a spotty record of antagonizing and intimidating the media. Won games. Never won a conference title with South Carolina. Took home one national title, lost another. At Florida, dominated the SEC like no coach since Bryant; at South Carolina, couldn't quite solve an Alabama, an LSU, an Auburn.
And he left on his own terms, as expected, with the legacy intact. "I want to be able to walk out of here," Spurrier said when he left Florida in 2001. "I don't want have to run out. I don't want to be chewed up and spit out."
STEVE SPURRIER THROUGH THE YEARS
Steve Spurrier compiled a record of 228-89-2 as a college football coach. Jeremy Brevard, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Steve Spurrier led Florida to the 1996 championship, the Gators' first. JOHN RAOUX, Associated Press Fullscreen Steve Spurrier was 122-27-1 in 12 seasons at Florida. Craig Bailey, Gannett Fullscreen Steve Spurrier gets a Gatorade bath from future No. 1 NFL draft pick Jadeveon Clowney after South Carolina defeatedWisconsin 34-24in the Capital One Bowl onJan 1, 2014. David Manning, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Steve Spurrier was South Carolina's winningest coach, at 89-49. Joshua S. Kelly, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Steve Spurrier on the sidelines as South Carolina takes on Texas A&M on Aug. 28, 2014. Jeremy Brevard, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Steve Spurrier was known as much for his offensive acumen and he was for his way with words. And the media. Shanna Lockwood, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen In addition to successful runs at Florida and South Carolina, Steve Spurrier won the 1966 Heisman Trophy with the Gators and also coached Duke University and the Washington Redskins. Joshua S. Kelly,USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen South Carolina head coach Steve Spurrier talks to his team during the first half against the Miami Hurricanes in the 2014 Independence Bowl. Nelson Chenault, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Steve Spurrier and South Carolina opened the 2015season with a victory against North Carolina. The Gamecocks are 1-4 since. Joshua S. Kelly, Joshua S. Kelly-USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen "(Steve Spurrier) will go down as one of the great coaches in the game," Hall of Fame former Georgia coach Vince Dooley says. Derick E. Hingle, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Steve Spurrier was an unsuccessful 12-20 in two years with the NFL's Washingon Redskins. Losing records were very unfamiliar to him and Spurrier observers. But the scrunched-up face and visor toss certainly looked familiar. Phil Coale, AP Fullscreen Like this topic?
